description: From Middle English epiphanie, from Old French epyphanie, from Late Latin epiphania, from Ancient Greek ἐπιφάνεια (epipháneia, “manifestation, striking appearance”), from ἐπιφαίνω (epiphaínō, “I appear, display”), from ἐπί (epí, “upon”) + φαίνω (phaínō, “I shine, appear”). English Epiphany (of Christ) since the 14th century, generic use since the 17th century.

entries.meaning: An illuminating realization or discovery, often resulting in a personal feeling of elation, awe, or wonder.
examples: Synonyms: aha moment, enlightenment, nirvana, satori
It came to her in an epiphany what her life's work was to be.

entries.meaning: A manifestation or appearance of a divine or superhuman being.
